There exists infinitely many deficient numbers

type: {n | n.Deficient}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_deficient
docString: There exists infinitely many deficient numbers

The theorem asserts that 1 cannot be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, making it an odd number in the given definition of even and odd numbers.

name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.10
docString: The theorem asserts that 1 cannot be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, making it an odd number in the given definition of even and odd numbers.

This theorem states that for every set `s` of natural numbers `ℕ`, given that `s` is infinite (`Infinite ↑s`), for any element `x` in `s`, there exists a natural number `n` such that the sum of `x`, `n`, and 1 is also an element in the set `s`. In other words, we can always find a natural number `n` so that moving `n` plus one steps from any number in an infinite set of natural numbers will still keep us within the set.

type: ∀ {s : Set ℕ} [inst : Infinite ↑s] (x : ↑s), ∃ n, ↑x + n + 1 ∈ s
name: Nat.Subtype.exists_succ
docString: This theorem states that for every set `s` of natural numbers `ℕ`, given that `s` is infinite (`Infinite ↑s`), for any element `x` in `s`, there exists a natural number `n` such that the sum of `x`, `n`, and 1 is also an element in the set `s`. In other words, we can always find a natural number `n` so that moving `n` plus one steps from any number in an infinite set of natural numbers will still keep us within the set.

There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set

type: ∀ {α : Type u} {a : Set α}, a.Finite → {b | b ⊆ a}.Finite
name: Set.Finite.finite_subsets
docString: There are finitely many subsets of a given finite set

For every finite set of natural numbers, there exists a natural number that is an upper bound for the set.

type: ∀ (s : Finset ℕ), ∃ n, s ⊆ Finset.range n
name: Finset.exists_nat_subset_range
docString: For every finite set of natural numbers, there exists a natural number that is an upper bound for the set.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, `n` is odd if and only if it is not even. In the context of a semiring, a number `n` is odd if there exists another number `k` such that `n` equals `2*k + 1`. On the other hand, a number `n` is even if there exists a number `r` such that `n` equals `r + r`. Therefore, this theorem establishes the mutually exclusive and exhaustive nature of odd and even numbers in the set of natural numbers.

type: ∀ {α : Sort u_1} {a b : α}, (a = b) = (b = a)
name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.4
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, `n` is odd if and only if it is not even. In the context of a semiring, a number `n` is odd if there exists another number `k` such that `n` equals `2*k + 1`. On the other hand, a number `n` is even if there exists a number `r` such that `n` equals `r + r`. Therefore, this theorem establishes the mutually exclusive and exhaustive nature of odd and even numbers in the set of natural numbers.

**Bertrand's Postulate**: For any positive natural number, there is a prime which is greater than
it, but no more than twice as large.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), n ≠ 0 → ∃ p, Nat.Prime p ∧ n < p ∧ p ≤ 2 * n
name: Nat.exists_prime_lt_and_le_two_mul
docString:
**Bertrand's Postulate**: For any positive natural number, there is a prime which is greater than
it, but no more than twice as large.

A product of finite numbers is still finite.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, (∀ a ∈ s, f a < ⊤) → ∏ a ∈ s, f a < ⊤
name: ENNReal.prod_lt_top
docString: A product of finite numbers is still finite.

Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

type: (s : Set ℕ) → [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ s] → [inst : Infinite ↑s] → Denumerable ↑s
name: Nat.Subtype.denumerable
docString: Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

In `Fin n`, all elements are odd for odd `n`,
otherwise an element is odd iff its `Fin.val` value is odd.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ} [inst : NeZero n] {k : Fin n}, Odd k ↔ Odd n ∨ Odd ↑k
name: Fin.odd_iff
docString:
In `Fin n`, all elements are odd for odd `n`,
otherwise an element is odd iff its `Fin.val` value is odd.

name: Nat.evenOddStrongRec

A sum is infinite iff one of the summands is infinite.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {s : Finset α} {f : α → ENNReal}, ∑ x ∈ s, f x = ⊤ ↔ ∃ a ∈ s, f a = ⊤
name: ENNReal.sum_eq_top
docString: A sum is infinite iff one of the summands is infinite.

The strong pigeonhole principle for infinitely many pigeons in
finitely many pigeonholes.  If there are infinitely many pigeons in
finitely many pigeonholes, then there is a pigeonhole with infinitely
many pigeons.

See also: `Finite.exists_ne_map_eq_of_infinite`

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {β : Type u_2} [inst : Infinite α] [inst : Finite β] (f : α → β), ∃ y, Infinite ↑(f ⁻¹' {y})
name: Finite.exists_infinite_fiber
docString:
The strong pigeonhole principle for infinitely many pigeons in
finitely many pigeonholes.  If there are infinitely many pigeons in
finitely many pigeonholes, then there is a pigeonhole with infinitely
many pigeons.

See also: `Finite.exists_ne_map_eq_of_infinite`

The inequality which contradicts Bertrand's postulate, for large enough `n`.

name: bertrand_main_inequality
docString: The inequality which contradicts Bertrand's postulate, for large enough `n`.

A sum is infinite iff one term is infinite.

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_1} {α : Type u_2} [inst : AddCommMonoid α] {s : Finset ι} {f : ι → WithBot α},
  ∑ i ∈ s, f i = ⊥ ↔ ∃ i ∈ s, f i = ⊥
name: WithBot.sum_eq_bot_iff
docString: A sum is infinite iff one term is infinite.

The pigeonhole principle for infinitely many pigeons in finitely many pigeonholes. If there are
infinitely many pigeons in finitely many pigeonholes, then there are at least two pigeons in the
same pigeonhole.

See also: `Fintype.exists_ne_map_eq_of_card_lt`, `Finite.exists_infinite_fiber`.

type: ∀ {α : Sort u_4} {β : Sort u_5} [inst : Infinite α] [inst : Finite β] (f : α → β), ∃ x y, x ≠ y ∧ f x = f y
name: Finite.exists_ne_map_eq_of_infinite
docString:
The pigeonhole principle for infinitely many pigeons in finitely many pigeonholes. If there are
infinitely many pigeons in finitely many pigeonholes, then there are at least two pigeons in the
same pigeonhole.

See also: `Fintype.exists_ne_map_eq_of_card_lt`, `Finite.exists_infinite_fiber`.

The pigeonhole principle for finitely many pigeons counted by heads: there is a pigeonhole with
at least as many pigeons as the ceiling of the average number of pigeons across all pigeonholes.
("The maximum is at least the mean" specialized to integers.)

More formally, given a function between finite sets `s` and `t` and a natural number `n` such that
`#t * n < #s`, there exists `y ∈ t` such that its preimage in `s` has more than `n`
elements.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : DecidableEq β] {s : Finset α} {t : Finset β} {f : α → β} {n : ℕ},
  (∀ a ∈ s, f a ∈ t) → t.card * n < s.card → ∃ y ∈ t, n < (Finset.filter (fun x => f x = y) s).card
name: Finset.exists_lt_card_fiber_of_mul_lt_card_of_maps_to
docString:
The pigeonhole principle for finitely many pigeons counted by heads: there is a pigeonhole with
at least as many pigeons as the ceiling of the average number of pigeons across all pigeonholes.
("The maximum is at least the mean" specialized to integers.)

More formally, given a function between finite sets `s` and `t` and a natural number `n` such that
`#t * n < #s`, there exists `y ∈ t` such that its preimage in `s` has more than `n`
elements.

Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p ≥ n`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ Nat.Prime p
name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString:
Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p ≥ n`.

If the union of disjoint measurable sets has finite measure, then there are only
finitely many members of the union whose measure exceeds any given positive number.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {ι : Type u_5} [inst : MeasurableSpace α] (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α) {ε : ENNReal},
  0 < ε →
    ∀ {As : ι → Set α},
      (∀ (i : ι), MeasurableSet (As i)) → Pairwise (Disjoint on As) → μ (⋃ i, As i) ≠ ⊤ → {i | ε ≤ μ (As i)}.Finite
name: MeasureTheory.Measure.finite_const_le_meas_of_disjoint_iUnion
docString:
If the union of disjoint measurable sets has finite measure, then there are only
finitely many members of the union whose measure exceeds any given positive number.

The set of finite `ℝ≥0∞` numbers is homeomorphic to `ℝ≥0`.

type: ↑{a | a ≠ ⊤} ≃ₜ NNReal
name: ENNReal.neTopHomeomorphNNReal
docString: The set of finite `ℝ≥0∞` numbers is homeomorphic to `ℝ≥0`.

**Hermite Theorem**. Let `N` be an integer. There are only finitely many number fields
(in some fixed extension of `ℚ`) of discriminant bounded by `N`.

type: ∀ (A : Type u_2) [inst : Field A] [inst_1 : CharZero A] (N : ℕ), {K | |NumberField.discr ↥↑K| ≤ ↑N}.Finite
name: NumberField.finite_of_discr_bdd
docString:
**Hermite Theorem**. Let `N` be an integer. There are only finitely many number fields
(in some fixed extension of `ℚ`) of discriminant bounded by `N`.

The pigeonhole principle for finitely many pigeons counted by heads: there is a pigeonhole with
at most as many pigeons as the floor of the average number of pigeons across all pigeonholes.  ("The
minimum is at most the mean" specialized to integers.)

More formally, given a function `f`, a finite sets `s` in its domain, a finite set `t` in its
codomain, and a natural number `n` such that `#s < #t * n`, there exists `y ∈ t` such that
its preimage in `s` has less than `n` elements.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} {β : Type v} [inst : DecidableEq β] {s : Finset α} {t : Finset β} {f : α → β} {n : ℕ},
  s.card < t.card * n → ∃ y ∈ t, (Finset.filter (fun x => f x = y) s).card < n
name: Finset.exists_card_fiber_lt_of_card_lt_mul
docString:
The pigeonhole principle for finitely many pigeons counted by heads: there is a pigeonhole with
at most as many pigeons as the floor of the average number of pigeons across all pigeonholes.  ("The
minimum is at most the mean" specialized to integers.)

More formally, given a function `f`, a finite sets `s` in its domain, a finite set `t` in its
codomain, and a natural number `n` such that `#s < #t * n`, there exists `y ∈ t` such that
its preimage in `s` has less than `n` elements.

If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Odd (n % a) ↔ Odd n)
name: Odd.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is odd iff `n % a` is odd.

To prove Fermat's Last Theorem, it suffices to prove it for odd prime exponents.

type: (∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p → Odd p → FermatLastTheoremFor p) → FermatLastTheorem
name: FermatLastTheorem.of_odd_primes
docString: To prove Fermat's Last Theorem, it suffices to prove it for odd prime exponents.
